title: Tiny Toy Dump Truck with Cam Action Bed

description.text: This is a variation of the Tiny Toy Dump Truck that does require support in order to print. The use of support allows cylindrical wheels, a bed axle sleeve that is no longer sliced, and the addition of a cam and rod that lifts the bed once per rotation of the back axle. It can be printed as a single piece on a standard Reprap/Makerbot by manually introducing support material during the print. See http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=47iEXR6xXnE for a video of a working copy that was printed on a standard Reprap.

See http://reprap.org/wiki/Manual_Support for a more detailed description (with images) of how to print using manual support. La Doll clay can be use as support material. Skeinforge should be configured so that comments are kept in the generated GCODE file. Export -> Comment Choice -> Do Not Delete Comments A tall skirt should be generated in Skeinforge. This can be accomplished by activating the Skirt module and setting the layers to a large value: Skirt -> Layers To (index) -> 100000 Examine the Skeinlayer window and determine the z-depth of the layers that need support. Assuming you are printing with 0.2mm layers, the layers for this object are: 4.0 (body bridges the lower pair of wheels)
7.2 (cam and rod appear)
11.8 (body bridges cam and rod)
13.2 (upper bed axle sleeve appears)
15.2 (upper pair of wheels appear) Split the GCODE file into 6 pieces, where the first file includes everything up to but not including the start of the first layer that needs support. Again, assuming 0.2mm layers, the first file should stop just before the line: (<layer> 4.0 ) The second file should start with the line that starts the first layer that needs support and include everything up to but not including the second layer that needs support. Continue with this pattern until you have six files. It is useful to put a G1 Xa Xb line at the end of all but the last file in order to move the extruder off the body of the print (replace a and b with appropriate values - in my case 25 worked well for both values). Print the first file. When complete, move the extruder using the jog functions of your host program so that you object is well clear of the extruder. Fill in the area that needs support using some clay. The clay should rise to the height of the top of the last printed layer of plastic, but no higher. If the support is too high it will get caught up on the nozzle when the next layer is printed which will cause adhesion problems in other areas of the print. If the support is not high enough the next layer of plastic will not stick, or it it will pull away as even higher layers are printed on top. Repeat the the process with the second file, and so on. When all files have been printed remove the skirt and manually remove any external lumps of clay. Then put the object in a container and cover with water. Let it soak for at least an hour. The clay will become very soft and the majority of it will be relatively easy to remove using a brush or a toothpick. Finally, wash the entire object under running water. The PLA wheels are rather slippery and the axles have a lot of friction, so the cam action bed will only work on certain surfaces. Some fabrics work well. The sticky side of a piece of masking tape works very well.

author: Imminentfate

title: Replacement Universal Extruder Carrier for Two-Up with Universal mount for L-Cheapo 2.1W Laser Cutter/Etcher

description.text:
Hi, this is my first time uploading a thing.

This is a replacement universal extruder carrier for the QU-BD Two-Up printer. The face of the carrier is blank so you can glue (or mount) any other device you would like to on the Two-Up 3D printer.

Included is a mount modified from the files sent to me by the guys at Endurance Robots (www.endurancerobots.com) where I got the L-Cheapo Blue Diode 2.1W Laser.

For the laser mount, lay the circuit board into it just like it was with the one that came with it. Then use 2 M4 screws to mount the fan to the upper supports as shown.

What I've done was use Acetone to glue the two pieces together. Paint both sides with enough that you can see it pooling just a little, then stick them together. Arrange the parts so they are positioned where you want them and hold them together for a minute. Then set it down and allow at least an hour to dry.

Setting up 3D printer software to use the laser can be tricky. I use Simplify3D and was able to find a configuration that worked. The key element missing from the Simplify3D interface was that you need to have the printer print from the top down instead of the bottom up. I finally solved this by just flipping the model over.

The Two-Up printer that I have uses the Red Ramps 1.4 board. I hooked the laser up to the D9 screw-in port where a fan would normally be connected. Then I told Simplify3D to include M101, M102 and M103 commands for extruder retraction and made sure it was going to use retraction for every move, no matter how short the distance. Then I used the post processing command area to tell it to remove any existing M102, M106 and M107 commands, then replace all M101s with M106 S200 and all M103s with M107.

NOTE: The M106 S200 command. The 200 should be adjusted to suit the needs of the project. Burning paper or cardboard requires less power than burning wood or acrylic. Trial and error will tell you what power is needed. You want the power set so that it just barely burns so after multiple passes you get a nice brown burn instead of black with tinted edges.

Also, be sure and set infill for your model to 100%. Then watch the progress window on your computer. You'll want to stop the process before it draws all of the layers. You'll have to judge for yourself when to stop it.

WARNING: DO NOT PUT ANY METAL UNDER THE LASER!!!! Metal will reflect the laser beam and can literally send the beam anywhere in the room. If anyone nearby is hit with the laser and isn't wearing protective goggles it can severely and permanently damage their eyes. Treat the laser with the respect it deserves, they are dangerous if not handled properly.

description.text: I needed some small I-Beams for a project so I decided to make one of my own.  The beam is 150 mm long x 10mm high x 5 mm wide.  The holes are 3.0 mm diameter.  I am fairly new to CAD, so I this is only my 2nd design using sketchup.

I printed it in PLA, using a raft to minimize warping.  I had tried one design that had the flanges perpendicular to the build platform and the web horizontal (like an H) but that didn't allow me to add holes.  I had to add fillets to the intersection of flange and web to allow me to print without supports.  It worked fairly well.

It's a pump, that looks like a house!
...
Ok that wasn't all too funny I admit. But it really is a tiny pump made for your aquarium! All you have to do is connect one air line to it and then another tube to move water wherever you want. In the tank, to a filter, or onto somebody!

It looks sort of cozy and I've arranged a few in different sizes to look like a village. So far no shrimps have been sucked up into it but the one I'm using is also very small.

I use mine to lift water up to a gravel filter in a pet bottle and it works quite well after a month. The hose got a bit clogged up but that's to expect from regular 4mm air tubes.

As I worked with this in autodesk I'm sorry to say that it's not scaled properly. It didn't matter much to me as the M3D has no way of measuring your prints either so I had to guess.
This did however force me to experiment a bit with different designs and here's what I came up with:
You want to have the thing stand tall and quite thin. The limitations of using a 4mm hose is that you can't trap enough air to lift the water high enough if the bell is too flat. Making it thin and tall also makes the hose connectors a bit more universal as they are tapered and thickens further down. You could make the thing big enough to hold the tubes outside diameter inside the holes as well. I also noticed that you want excess air for almost all setups, at least with the 4mm hose. If the tube gets clogged with dirty water the bell will just spew air out the intake so instead I tried to keep the water in the tube to a minimum. Of course, a bigger bell will alleviate this problem. It'll also need a weight at the bottom, or if it's big enough something inside to weight it down like rocks or course gravel.

author: cxam5

title: Quick Flip - fast swicth between HBP and ABP

description.text: Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8878 and until I get the ABP to do what it is supposed to do for all height prints, I have created a simple systems to switch between the two. It requires one more MBI heater board ( http://store.makerbot.com/makerbot-thingomatic-heater-board-v1-1.html ) so there is no dismantling necessary. The idea is to replace the X stage front and back plates with printed counterparts (one could use the wooden pieces but the removal would probably injure it eventually) and to install a pair of clips to the underside of the ABP and the HBP. The ABP will require 4 extra holes (exactly where the HBP has them) but otherwise the transformation is reversible (important to me). The HBP has 4 thumbscrews to adjust height in each corner and the ABP is being modified further to use a Stainless Stell belt as seen here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9127 along with a servo driven "tensioner" that tenses the standard length belt during printing so some more stable height gain can be obtained from the ABP but releases whenever the belt needs to moves. I will post this one when I am done building and testing it. I have added the SketchUp files for your editing pleasure.

• Print 2 Quick Flip plates and 2 pairs of clips.

  • Remove the wooden bases from the ABP and HBP. They are different and both came with my TOM.

  • Using the HPB as guide, mark the 4 holes to be drilled on the ABP as shown in the pictures (they are the 4 outermost holes.

  • Countersink the holes in the printed clips so the 3mm screw heads are out of the way when fully in place. Look at the pictures to see which side is to be countersunk. You will need to use 10 or 12 mm screws or just cut longer ones like I did ( be sure to file the sharp edges left). If you cut them outside of their final place remember to set a nut or two in the screws so you can recreate the start of the screw "spiral" after all the cutting and filing is done.

  • Before gluing the clips, place them in the future positions and check the precise position where the two halves will be glued together later with ABS cement, Acetone, Methyl Ethyl Ketone (MEK) or any glue that works.

  • Remove them from the wood and glue it accordingly.

  • Remove the front and back plate of the X- Stage and replace with the Quick Flip plates (I tried to print in two colors to see the text better - it has no mechanical effect :) .Be careful with the wooden parts of the X- stage while putting the plates one - I broke the corner on the front on both sides and needed to "gorilla glue" it. A next step would be to remove the whole X-stage and replace the side plates with something like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9626 but I decided not just yet.

  • Before putting the HPB and ABP together, test the fit between clips and plates. I needed to remove part of the black plastic connector in the heater board for the HBP so it would not interfere with the wooden plate as I wanted maximum X-height gain. I also needed to remove some material in the HBP clips to create some space for the thumbscrews to fit under the HBP. Adjust accordingly in your case. The clips should miss the Z-rods by a few mms when homing - be sure to check.

  • The HPB adjustment thumbscrews I printed are attached but there are better designs in thingiverse as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9094 - the adjustment uses 4 disposable pen springs and the same countersunk 3mm screws used earlier.

  • You may need to lengthen your cable (that connects to the ABP/HBP) as you move the HBP connector to the front of the X-stage. Mine barely made but I ultimately increased its length some 200 mm more - carefully removed the metal pins, opened them with a small plier to be able to use it again and soldered the wire after the wire was in place again in the original plastic connector.
    • Use and improve it to your hearts content. :)

comments.text: I'd like to say - Congrats. Good post.
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: That is a good suggestion. There is precious little space on the back side with the Z-rods there so it would have to designed on the inside (between the clips and the x-stage) so it may be hard to get your fingers in there. You will also need to get the Z-stage a lot more out of the way than if you reach each clip from the sides and "pop" them out on the back and then on the front. The other aspect is that the clips are, on purpose, rather solid so they require some effort to bend - the bar would have to be strong for these clips. Some easier clips would work a lot better with a cross bar.
comments.author: bstott

title: Pocket Breach: Starship Duels on the go!

description.text:
This is "Breach: Starship Duels" just slightly smaller. The tiles are reduced to the size of the Pocket Tactics/Pocket Dungeon sizes, which allows the user to user the Pocket Tactics trays.

I've used the solid trays here, despite more plastic, because I like the contrast on the hollow tiles. I've also merged all the rulebooks, and did a little reformating/editing. Hopefully I didn't leave anything out.

I didn't include the Hazard or Utility miniatures, deciding to just use the tiles since this game is supposed to be portable.

Lastly, I haven't printed the box yet... I'll update it if I find out its too small.

Many things to the folks at Ill Gotten Games ( http://www.illgottengames.net/ ) for the original game, and being so cool about sharing it.

Enjoy!

comments.text: I just finished printing this out in PLA. It printed quite well. I also created an insert to hold the hexes, dice, and pieces. Would you like to add it?

comments.text: something i have done to reduce print time on my relatively slow printer is make the ships themselves into chips. it also lets them fit into a bag or case more easily, ive also modified the rules so that instead of moving a ship onto a tile, the ship replaces that tile, and every tile it traversed to get there. these tiles go into a tile pool of the ships controller, who can then place them into other spots in contact with the tile set. this allows the tile set to shift and adapt, adding yet another level of strategy. anyway... back to the point. if you ever make another miniaturization, perhaps consider having the outline represent a ship

author: wojo661

title: M3 Nut bed leveling thumb wheel

description.text:
Designed specifically for the bed leveling screws on the Wanhao i3. A common mod is to add some M3 nuts to the bed for more stability. My package had extra nylock nuts so I replaced the wing nuts with nylock M3's and these thumb screws. A massive improvement when leveling.

Specifically designed for these nuts: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001BHLSTI?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00

EDIT: doubled number of teeth, generally cleaned up model

EDIT 2: Made nut 1mm smaller in diameter per feedback in comments section.
Regular PLA at whatever settings work for you will be fine

comments.text: Best wheels I found so far.Thank you
comments.author: Celphor

comments.text: At first I thought these were brilliant but they touch the printer frame!! They are just too wide. When the bed moves to its ends of the Y axis, the thumb wheels contact the printer frame and actually turn which kind of defeats the purpose.
comments.author: StuntDouble

comments.text: Interesting. On my printer, it's nowhere close to touching the frame. Perhaps the design of the i3 has changed slightly over time. The openscad file is attached, you should be able to scale the design to whatever size you like.
comments.author: StuntDouble

comments.text: Good work! The hole for the nuts was on the smaller side but a hammer and punch fixed that right up.
comments.author: blackbird68

comments.text: Work very well, much easier than the wing nuts - great
comments.author: johnrod

comments.text: Same here. Wanhao i3 first version . . .
comments.author: gurzo

comments.text: Made this default with 13mm radius, but this made the thumbscrews hit the y-axis vertical plate of my new i3 V2 (the one with angled LCD). I had to reduce radius to 12mm to clear the y-axis support plates. Download OpenSCAD, open the attached file and edit the radius before printing.
comments.author: Geir68

comments.text: Same, I printed the original thing but sanded it down so it wouldn't strike the y axis plates. Thanks OP, but suggest you drop the diameter 0.5-1mm.

comments.text: Glad it's not just me - it actually adjusts the bed level while it's printing (if your print is at the extremities of the bed).
comments.author: Geir68

author: jimbojsb

description.text:
Simple functional wall-mounted spool holder.
Spool holder also functions un-mounted.

I wanted a spool holder that was printable but did not consume too much plastic. Mounting the spool on the wall also makes great use of vertical space and keeps my desk less cluttered. This holder can easily support a 1kg spool on plaster board (dry-wall).

Requires some nuts, bolts and nails easily sourced from any hardware store.

I have also included spool-608 bearing adaptors for colorfabb and makergeeks spools, filaments that I currently use. These adaptors allow the spool to rotate smoothly on the rod shaft. 608 bearings were sourced from ebay.

Print:

  • 1 left side
  • 1 right side
  • 1 wall hook

My print settings:
slicer: simplify3D
shells: 3
solid layers: 2
infil: 15 %
extrusion width: 0.4 mm
layer height: 0.3 mm
printer: Printrbot simple metal

Non-printed parts:

  • 3x 5/16 4 inch threaded hex bolt (readily available from any hardware store. M8 may also work. Use longer rods if your spool is unusually wide)
  • 6x 5/16 nuts (M8 may also work)
  • 3x small wall nails

Spool holder assembly:

  1. Take one side of the spool holder and insert 2 nuts into the inset holes.
  2. Screw in 2 threaded hex bolts all the way such that the spool holder is firmly secured between the bolt and nut
  3. Screw on an additional nut to each bolt
  4. Inset the other side of the spool holder
  5. Fasten with the remaining 2 nuts

Mounting the wall hook:

  1. Place 2 small nails in the angled holes on the wall hook
  2. Position the hook on the wall and hammer in the angled nails
  3. Hammer in a third nail in the top hole to secure the hook

Hang spool holder on wall.
Insert 3rd threaded rod through spool and mount on spool holder.
(Use of spool-608 bearing adaptor is optional but recommended)

If you want to stand the spool on a desk, adding some blu-tak or poster putty under the "feet" makes for a great non-slip surface.

description.text:
Here's the first unofficial accessory pack for m_bergman's excellent WWII "Tanks and Vehicles" collection.

In this accessory pack I've added or modified the following for several vehicles (German at this point, Americans likely next)

NOTE: Though the models are still at the original 1:200 scale, I'm printing mine at 1:100; I can't promise the fine details will come through on smaller scales.

  1. Separate tracks that can be printed with little or no support; makes cleanup much easier and prevents some of the distortions that occur when trying to print the entire vehicle. Also allows smooth bottoms on the vehicles with support only needed for overhanging tread guards and the like.

  2. Detailed treads and wheels that can add more realism when printing at larger scales.

  3. Addition of Pioneer bridges to allow conversion of Sd Kfz 251/1 to 251/7 Pioneer transport.

  4. Additon of my own version of the Opel Maultier (adapted from Bergman's Opel Blitz) with scratch designed highly detailed tracks.

  5. Addition of my own Sd Kfz 7/1. It also has highly detailed tracks that look great at 1/100 scale. I used the Bergman wirbelwind as the basis for the turret, and I tried to push the envelope a little by adding hands and additional detail to the little German dudes. I also added separately printable rails to allow a rails down configuration. Note: cleanup of the support material for the turret is not for the faint of heart. I used a dental pick and stabbed myself several times.

  6. Addition of a commander version of the turrets and a separately printable hatch to allow "commander" versions of some of the vehicles. I used German tank crew figures from Peter Pig and Plastic Soldier Co.

  7. Separately printed schurzen as appropriate. For the Jagdpanzer IV's which didn't have the rail, I made little posts from plastic rod and glued them to the tracks to support the schurzen for gluing, probably should have added them digitally to the stl file, but I got lazy.

  8. Jagdpanzer IV and Jagdpanther can used the Panzer IV and Panther A detailed tracks, respectively.

  9. I just added a Opel Radio truck with the bedspring antenna. I modified Bergman's Opel Blitz to create it.

Update: 11/3/16 - Added Churchill IV. I have not yet test printed it. Add a comment (good or bad :) ) if you've tried to print it

Available in this release:

NOTE(again): Though the models are still at the original 1:200 scale, I'm printing mine at 1:100; I can't promise the fine details will come through on smaller scales. Note I've included some of m_bergman's turrets unaltered to make models complete

Jagdpanzer IV: separate detailed tracks (use PzKfw IV), commander hull and hatch, separate schurzen
Kubelwagon: separate wheels
Marder III: separate detailed tracks
Flakpanzer 38: separate detailed tracks
Opel Maultier: separate highly detailed tracks, detailed wheels, flat-bottomed body
Panther(A-late): separate detailed tracks, commander turret and hatch
Jagdpanther (late): separate detailed tracks (use Panther A), commander hull and hatch
Panzer IV: separate detailed tracks, commander turret and hatch, schurzen
RSO: separate detailed tracks
SdKfz7-1: NEW UNIT, Body with rails, Body without rails, separate rails, enhanced figures in turret
234-2 Puma, separate detailed wheels, commander turret and hatch
SdKfz 250: separate detailed tracks and wheels, bodies for /1, /7, /8, /9, and /10 variants
SdKfz 251: separate detailed tracks and wheels, bodies for /1, /9, and /10 variants, assault bridges for /7 pioneer variant
Tiger: separate detailed tracks, commander turret and hatch
Wespe: separate detailed tracks
Opel Radio Truck: Separate wheels, radio cabin, antenna and truck chassis.

Printing and Assembly tips:

I printed the units in the pictures in ABS at 200% scale sliced at 0.1mm, though I've had excellent success with PLA recently @ 0.15mm and 0.1mm. I print some of the bulk units (like the 40 or so Sd Kfz 250's and 251's I've done so far) at 0.2 and they look fine, just a little more stair stepped. I've also remedied some issues at 0.1 where holes appear at the top of my print by slicing a little thicker (0.15 usually).

For wheels, hatches and other small pieces, I've avoided problems with bed adhesion by printing with support but no raft, and I've adjusted a parameter to extend the support 3-4 mm outside the edge. this joins together the parts in a web, and allows multiple parts to be printed at once with good adhesion.

Cleanup is essential for good parts fit. Emery boards, sanding sticks, files, dental picks, etc are your best friend. If you have a sharp 1/2" woodworking chisel, it will help a lot to clean up support material under tread guards. Above all, be careful with the sharp stuff - keep your fingers out of the path where it will slip because it WILL.

For commander models, I've found that printed the hatches a little large (~10%) looks and works better.

I glue up the units with Loctite Ultra Gel Control. It's one of the only super glues that i've used that I can actually use up before it dries up. Plus it's cheap and available at home stores.

Let me know any questions or comments and good luck. Americans are just about finished and will come next.

title: SUSPENSION UPGRADE AND INSPECTION ROBOT FITOUT FOR DAGU T'REX TANK

description.text:
The Dagu T'Rex tank chassis is great but:

  • The suspension capacity doesn't match the motor capacity
  • It throws it's tracks a bit too often
  • the tracks become misaligned and then slip on the drive gear

The attached files are for a suspension upgrade (helper springs - you keep the originals too) and an assembly to carry a high mounted cctv camera, video TX, a RC receiver and some rails to which you could fit just about anything. We are going to fit LIDAR.

I've attached lots of photos that should explain how it all goes together and the components in the Rhino file are laid out in-line for assembly. If it makes no sense let me know.

I've also attached the Rhino file so you can easily modify anything you like.

You will need 100mm RC Car suspension, and some M5 and M3 screws in addition to the printed parts.

First job: drill holes in the original suspension arms that you attach the upgraded parts. There is a drilling guide for this - see the photo for how that works.

Next job: there are spacers (look like rods) that are 90mm long. assemble the suspension using these instead of the springs. These put the suspension mounts in the right spot. You can test for clearance etc then drill the holes. There is a photo for that too.

For the rest, I think you can figure it out from the photos.

NOTE: if the photos make sense to you, you know what you are doing. Otherwise, this is an expensive and not that simple project. Have a long think about it before drilling holes in your T'Rex if you're not sure you need to do this!

remixed_from.title: Wanhao i3 Z endstop - No extra bolts needed

description.text:
An adjustable Z-axis endstop holder which requires no screws! Just push the micro switch into the holder and slide it onto the frame. It holds tightly onto the frame but allows for quick and easy adjustment when needed.

This part was designed to fit against my tolerances, so your results may vary.

OnShape document: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/03fdd67aac0244cba136c0b3/w/3785faa0f94e4de88542cc7c/e/4954b1b805c346359d5c9445

comments.text: I just wanted to tell you this is probably the single best improvement I have made to my Monoprice Maker Select Plus / Wanhao Duplicator i3 that I have done.  What a huge improvement in being able to just slide your Z axis endstop to where you want and not be limited to those fixed mounting screws.  I was able to finally tweak my Z height correctly for my glass bed and Micro Swiss and can now properly level my bed again.  (Previously my perfect Z height was in between the 4 screw hole options.)  A simple mod that is genius in its functionality.  Nicely done.

comments.text: This holds the z-stop switch in exactly the right position, and it's really easy to dink around with the z-stop height. If you want to lock in the position in a semi-permanent way, a hot melt glue gun is perfect for this. Just glue around the edges of the part on the outside of the frame. If something ever happens where you want to remove it or reposition it after you glue it in place, simply spray down the joint with isopropyl alcohol, and after a few seconds, the glue will let go, and you can peel it right off! It's an old paintless dent repair trick.

title: HardyGraph - Dynamical generated and fully printed 3D-Printer

description.text:
Hello everybody,

This is a fully generated 3-D Printer made with OpenScad. Everything you need is in that one .scad file. Its your decision how you want to build it because of its parametric design. I reached a Workspace Area of 360x600x270mm (X/Y/Z). But its not that easy to build ;-) YouTube Video: https://youtu.be/ZJUT9yClOmQ

There is no Extruder at the moment because i use it for commercial selling plastic signs. Until 15.07.17 it produced around 3200 plastic signs without any defect parts (except milling tools of course). Some accuracy examples are here:
http://virtograv.de/Material/Referenzen/Schriftarten/
If there is any interest, I would design an baseplate for mounting an extruder on the X-Axis-Carrier.

All Information you need are written down by me at the following Link:
https://github.com/VirToReal/HardyGraph

More Description can be found in the RepRapWiki
http://reprap.org/wiki/HardyGraph

If there is any interest in my Project, I will work with more interest on the GitHub Wiki for a better description ;-)

comments.text: There are huge build space gains by NOT moving the build platform.  I've been particularly interested in such designs. :-)  Also, not moving the build platform at all makes it much easer to keep it level and offers alternative heating options  and building surface switch-out. Yea!  OpenSCAD rocks. :-)

print_settings.Notes:: Print jaws in a flexible material.

description.text: Universal, Fully 3D Printable Tripod Mount for Smartphones

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10-30%

Notes:

Print jaws in a flexible material.

Print the jaws in NinjaFlex (or your flexible filament of choice) with fairly low infill - it needs to be able to deform a couple millimeters for the tensioning mechanism to work correctly, and the flexible material protects phones without cases. I used 10% infill.

Use the long cylinders on the jaws to pull them through the mounting holes, then cut them off once assembled.

The hole on the bottom should be able to thread onto a standard tripod (with a bit of effort).

The tensioning mechanism is loosely based on vernier calipers. Two sets of holes with different spacing allows one set of holes to line up every 2mm, while keeping the pin relatively thick. Place your phone between the jaws, squeeze them together lightly, and push the pin into the hole that lines up.

I printed it on a Rep 2 with a glass build plate coated with a glue stick. My slicing profiles are attached.

comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text:
Hi, I just went to the SketchUp website, and although it's free, I don't have a Windows or Mac computer! I am running Linux, and I have a Android PC as well, but not Windows. I don't know what file format can SketchUp export, if it only works with STL files, then if you don't mind making the mod yourself it would be greatly appreciated! If it can export some other kind of 3d model solid file, then I can do it, let me know.
Yes, I would use a standard 1/4-20 UNC nut, I don't have one at the moment, so I can't really give you the size, but I'm sure it's easy to find on the net. If not, I'll go buy a few and let you know. It should fit real snug in the pocket so that it doesn't fall, although I would glue it in anyways.
comments.author: ereggia

comments.text:
Oh sorry, if I could add 1 more suggestion... if you do add the nut pocket, could you put it more in-line with where the phone would sit? Right now, the tapped hole is more towards the back, and it makes the setup "tippy" to the front. Specially if you had to orient the phone a little downwards, the whole thing would probably tip over. If the nut was exactly inline with the phone, it would add a lot of stability.
I hope I'm not being too picky, just trying to improve it after I tried it. Let me know what you think!
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text:
I may know what's causing your threads to strip out so easily. The logic is a bit weird, so bear with me. Looking at the make you posted, it seems like the tabs/flaps on either side of the pads that are supposed to hold the phone fit around the sides of the part it's connected to. That fit actually has no tolerance, and on most printers, wouldn't fit. You can see this in this make: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:157243 where the person had to break those tabs off to get the jaws in place, since they weren't flexible. My guess is that your printer is dialed in more than most off-the-shelf bots, and your prints are probably more "dimensionally accurate." If that is the case, the hole where the bolt screws in is probably a bit larger in diameter than if it were printed on other printers, making the threads not dig in too much, and the hole strips easier than usual (it's quite secure when I print it).
So, hopefully that makes sense, and kudos for getting your tolerances dialed in, if that's the cause.
Just making the hole slightly smaller could fix the issue, but I'll still put the nut in there.
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text:
Wow, that is really awesome, thank you very much for doing this!
Yeah, I spent some time to make my printer accurate. Those sides fit just perfectly on mine, like, perfect. So you may be right about the hole, it might be too big, that makes sense. I'd still prefer the steel nut though. I forgot about the ninjaflex little pins that would probably be where I want the nut to be, as you guessed, I just cut those off as I had no need for them.
I'll post it as a remix once I print it and see that it works good. Again, thanks a lot!!

title: Halo 4 Needler prop weapon with .SLT files
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Check out Printing the Revolution's video detailing the build and finish of this design.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F0XdU6xF-8o

Feeling generous and want to support my design work? Visit my Myminifactory page and leave a tip, It would be greatly appreciated.
https://www.myminifactory.com/users/EthanNewhouse

Good day loyal Thingiversites... Thingiversians??? Either way, hello and welcome to my most recent project. I have designed a Halo 4 Needler weapon. This is close to, but not a perfect replica of the weapon seen in the game. For a full scale model as in the game, scale up by 1.27. Thanks to Flynney for the reference scale. This is designed with custom LEDs (T10 & T5 LEDs) and switches in mind, pink and blue LEDs for the Needles and Lights. I am currently in the works of making this item printable and would like the feedback of the community on this. Anybody interested in this design or with suggestions, please comment below. Thank you for your continued interest in this project, I look forward to seeing what you make. There are two other models of this that I remixed for small build platforms, one with electronics and one without. Happy printing!

Progress update (1): Printing has begun. Estimated total material used including support material is approx 3Kg. Estimated printing time at .3 layer resolution is approx 166 hours. If you're planning on printing this project yourself, budget for about $80-90 in filament and $30 in electronics.

Progress update (2): While I am waiting for the filament to arrive in the mail, I decided to design up a stand for the Needler. Tell me what you think of the design in the comment section.

Progress update (3): By the request of a number of you who were kind enough to comment, the .STL files are available for download. Remember, this is a work in progress, so any problems you run into, let me know and I'll try my best to make appropriate changes.

Progress update (4): Two new models of this prop have been uploaded to thingiverse. Both models are cut to fit small build platforms, one with electronic cutouts and one without. Printing still in progress.

Progress update (5): Refined the trigger assembly to use a 12x12x9mm tac switch that is in the instructions under links. Added a Trigger button that allows you to press the switch through the trigger assembly hole. Printing is nearly complete.

Progress update (6): Would you believe that I received the wrong color of filament? believe it, 15 hours and 250g of material wasted. Printing of the Top Shell has begun. All that's left after that is 14 needles.

Links to the materials I used are at the end of these instructions.

The printing specs I am using are as follows. .4mm nozzle, .3mm layer height, support everywhere @35 degrees, 5 perimeters, 5 bottom and top solid layers, 60mm/s support and infill speed, 40mm/s outside perimeter speed, raft at .2mm air gap.

Approximate material usage and time is 3Kg and 171 hours

Each part is cut into segments that may be printed in the single color as it appears in game, purple, pink, grey, black.....

Print one of everything except for as follows. Print 14 alignment pin 9.5x38, print 4 alignment pin 9.5x18, print 4 LED holder front tip, print 7 LED holder back, print 14 Needles.

This design is made to use T10 LEDs in the needles and T5 LEDs in the tip and back. A 12vdc AA battery pack in a 2x4 configuration will fit in the battery hole on the top shell.

Please upload any makes. Happy printing!

Links:
-Purple PLA
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ITZOL3K?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FXOG246?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MEZDPS8?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00
-12x12x9mm tac switch
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HGAKKAC?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00
-T10 Pink LEDs
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GXUPQCS?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s01

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00K85BPB0?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s01

author: EthanNewhouse

description.text:
This RepRap Power Ring can be set to use "standard" ring sizes for around the world. Instead of having to enter the specific measurement you can simply select your region (there are 4 available) and then enter the ring size appropriate for that region.
So if you need a size 13 ring in the US, then the first parameter would be 0 (setting the region) and the second would be 13 (setting the size). There are 3 other parameters for things like thickness, depth of the logo, and whether the edges are beveled or not.
NOTE: The .stl is just a sample that creates a ring in the US/Canada size of 13. To set your own size edit the OpenSCAD file, render, and export your own .stl.

There are 5 parameters to set in the OpenSCAD file to customize the ring. 1) Sets ring sizing region. Values are:
0 for United States and Canada
1 for UK, Ireland, Australia & New Zealand (Please note: "" is needed around non-numerical values)
2 for India, China & Japan
3 for Switzerland
2) Sets internal ring size based on ring sizes for the region set in parameter 1.
3) Sets thickness of the ring (lengthways along the finger).
4) Sets depth of the RepRap logo embossed on the ring.
5) Sets whether the front edges are beveled or not.

comments.text: Okay, who wants to make the rest of the Captain Planet rings?

title: Prusa i3 Dial Indicator Bracket for Bed Leveling

description.text:
My version of a dial indicator bracket for bed leveling. Works on the folgertech prusa i3 stock y carriage. May work on others? Uses the stock nema 17 mount holes to mount the bracket.

See instructions for gauge specifics including measurements.

UPDATE 9/3/15 uploaded a new stl that looks a little better and uses slightly less material.

Specifically used a mitutoyo dial gauge model 1803-10. But most gauges with a 9.5mm lower diameter and a 6.5mm 90 degree attachment should work just fine. Has three mounting holes to adjust position depending on how long your probe is.

Printed at .2mm layer height and 20% infill.

author: Imminentfate

description.text:
This battery case can be printed in several parts if your printer is not big enough to do it in one time.
It fit 2 batteries pack like this :

Spec.
Capacity: 5000mAh
Voltage: 3S1P / 3 Cell / 11.1V
Discharge: 25C Constant / 35C Burst
Weight: 354g (including wire, plug & case)
Dimensions: 162x21x46mm
Balance Plug: JST-XH
Discharge Plug: 5.5mm Bullet

You can find them on hobbyking.
two packs connected in serie, will make a 6S 5000mah pack.
Should be enough for 10km range.

I just printed the 4 parts using my prusa i3.
Printed in ABS, heated bed at 100deg, nose at 250, 0.2mm layer, speed 80mm/s
Once the parts are printed, you can weld them together using ACETONE.
juste take a dish, put a thin layer of acetone inside.
put the frame of the box in the acetone for 10s or so, then stick the cover on it.
Keep them joined together few minutes, it should stick.
Then it will solder together and become harder when the acetone will be dry.

comments.text: Why didnt you just join the cover and the base together in your modelling program? Then just print it. Just curious
comments.author: Octane7

comments.text: it's just because if I joined them together (which I did at the beginning) I could not get a good result with the text on the cover because I had to print it upside down to limit the usage of supports.
comments.author: Octane7

comments.text: Nice

description.text:
The ZYYX Ball, a simple ball with ZYYX engraved on it.

Printed with TPU, and it had a great bounce to it :-)
For more information on printing with flexible filaments visit http://www.zyyx3dprinter.com/printing-with-soft-plastics-with-the-soft-spring-accessory/

Happy printing
//ZYYX Team

Print two copies of this model with a flexible filament, we used a TPU in this case.

Glue the halves together with a compatible glue, in our case superglue worked fine.

To get an even bounce in the ball we used the possibility to remove all bottom layers in Simplify3D and configured the shells and top layers to get a 2mm thick outer shell and a sparse infill.
In addition we used the multiple process features to create a flange for extra glueing area between the two halves.

Simplify3d Settings:
Process 1:
Layer height 0.2 mm
Extrusion Width 0,4 mm
0 Bottom Solid Layers
15% Infill
10 Outline Shells
10 Top Layers
stop printing at 1 mm.

Process 2:
Layer height 0.2 mm
Extrusion Width 0,4 mm
0 Bottom Solid Layers
15% Infill
5 Outline Shells
10 Top Layers
start printing at 1 mm

Happy Printing!
//ZYYX Team

title: Splint for immobilising injured finger customizable V1.0

description.text:
Create finger splint for injured finger.

It can be used on "proximal interphalangeal joints" (PIJ or PIP), those between the first (also called proximal) and second (intermediate) phalanges
or "distal interphalangeal joints" (DIJ or DIP), those between the second and third (distal) phalanges

Conditions to use:
Mallet finger
Swan Neck deformity
Boutonniere,
Lateral deviation
Trigger finger

https://youtu.be/zfQqDyHkZa8
https://youtu.be/UvACw1bYKsg

Use at your own risk.
Happy printing!

Well printed on felix printer in PLA with 0.100 layer. Keep it slow to allow cooling or print two or more pieces at once. I use raft for better adhesion. Length of a splint is 2*ExternalDiameter.
Printed with 100 % infill and no support.
Use natural PLA if you are going to wear it since you don't know what kind of color they use to minimize possibility of allergic reaction on skin.

comments.text: Thanks so much for publishing this! My friend made a joke about me making myself a splint and it turns out it was actually a great idea!

title: Tilted Extruder Motor mounts for Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D

description.text:
Been working on the "Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer" and wanted to use 2 Extruder-motors.

Unless I did some vertical midle-bracing, I found best placement would be to have them both in the same side, with the 2 filament spools in the opposite side.

I have titled the mount 22.5% degress and moved the motors a tad closer to the extrusion

The piece of bowden-tubing is just to show filament path.
Added a guide on the mount (goes into the extrusion groove) to help fixing the mount in place, but don't really know if it matters

I printed layerheight 0,2. I recommend using 100% infill to make it sturdy.. I will work with like 20% but screws are going to dig into it...

I recommend putting the cables from the motors into the groove in the extrusion.

author: dintid

description.text:
printed several parts in pla infill 20 %
(brand peha)

What is it?

Minimal design case for Arduino Mega2560 + Ramps 1.4 + SmartLCD + 60x60 Fan + ATX Connector. I've converted an ATX Power Supply to 12V 10A Power Supply to use with the 3D Printer, so i decided to try to use the ATX Connector for easy and clean cable mount for 4 Stepper Motor (16pins) + 3 Endstops (6pins). 

Does it work?

I still have no idea since i've never printed it, gonna try it out as soon as possible and write down a feedback in case it works (hope so).

What do you need for it?

  • 1xArduino Mega2560
  • 1xRamps 1.4
  • 1xSmartLCD
  • 1xHeatsink for each stepper driver
  • 1x60x60 Fan
  • 1xATX 24pin Connector
  • 2xM3 5mm cilindric head bolts
  • 4xM3 10mm cilindric head bolts
  • 4xbolts for Fan (size depends on fan)
  • 1xMain_Case.stl
  • 1xFan_Mount_A.stl
  • 1xFan_Mount_B.stl
  • 1xSmartLCD_Mount.stl
  • ATX_Connector_Mount.stl

Feel free to comment, ask, and (whynot?) to try it out leaving a feedback so to optimize project.

This is a model of the Great Sphinx that I've grabbed from Google Warehouse, cleaned up and converted to an STL file.
I was originally a little worried about the overhang from the chin area, but it ended up printing without any problems.

I would definitely recommend activating the Cool function on this one. It also gives the added benefit of slowing down for the finer details on the head.
Printed on a Thing-O-Matic MK6 with ABP.

title: Heavy *INTERLOCKING* M3D Filament Spool Holder Bushing

description.text:
I Didn't like/Couldn't Use ANY of the spool holder bushings that I found already designed for the M3D Spools successfully...
(They would keep walking out of the spool and then my spool would drop onto the spindle of my filament holder and everything would get all screwed up...)
Soooo... I decided to redesign one that would work. It was designed in ScorchCAD for Android which can be found in the Play Store...

These Bushings work well with:
THING 705345
(It seems like after browsing that most people choose this spool holder first anyway (>.<)
Or with any spindle size under 14mm.

Leave Me a Comment, Let me know what you like, what you don't like, Improvements, Ideas, etc.

Most of all I want...To see YOUR makes of this!!

If you have any other things that you would like designed for your micro give me a shout, If I can do it & I have the time, I would be more than happy to help (^_^)

Printed on the Micro by M3D Neon Orange
Using M3D Beta Software v1.3.6
Filament Used was M3D Onyx Black PLA @ 215C

Print Settings used:
                               Medium(Slow) Print Quality
                               Medium(Slow) Infill
                               Supports - NO
                               Model on Model Support - NO
                               Wave - Yes
                               Raft - YES (but its really up to you, I just wanted a cleaner look for the outsides of the Bushings, they don't NEED a raft to print successfully in PLA ;-)

title: Durafly EFX Racer Slope Glider Nose

description.text:
Alternative printed glider nose cones for the Hobbyking Durafly EFX Racer, STL's created by my friend Leonard Hall (of 3D printed quadcopter fame).

Two noses to choose from.
Nose type 1 is standard length with the air scoop blanked off.
Nose type 2 is stretched and smoothed out (air scoop is smoothed out).

The photo is of Nose type 2, which is my choice for the slope.
It has been lightly sanded after printing, and been brushed with Acetone and left under a glass jar on a saucer for 45 minutes to gloss over. It was supported from inside by a wire post while under the jar.

Printed in ABS.
I set the heated bed up to 105C and ran the filament quite hot too to avoid cracking.
To compensate for ABS shrinkage up-scaling by 1% might be a good thing. I printed at normal scale and found the fit tight but OK after a light sand inside the mouth.

title: Kossel Carriages - For Use With Switchfector V3

description.text: This is modified from another thingiverse carriage. It is perfect for the switchfector v3. I use it with titanium rods, and I use rubber bands (3 each side) to pull the rods into the magnets. Even at high speed and raised plastic it survives.

Print qty 3. You need m3 bolts, and nuts for the rod ends, a long m3 screw to pull the third wheel against the rail. The nut for this goes in the back before you put on rail. Use pliers to insert. Put the two vwheels on one side, then put it on the vertical rail, then put the third wheel. As I use prethreaded rodes, I mounted the rod ends, and then screwed the rods into the ends. The other side of my rods have screw on balls.

description.text:
Magnets are underutilized in today's society. You can help fix this by using a magnetic battery holding system for your multirotor. Uses two 25.2mm (1 inch) magnets in combination with two steel washers taped to the battery.

(Recommended not to be used near a magnet compass for obvious reasons)

-Buy magnets like this or similiar:
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/One-Small-Disc-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-N50-Grade-Magnet-25mm-x-10mm-Ring-Hole-5mm-/171193250638?hash=item27dbe9b34e
-Print required holder
-Glue magnets to holder
-Zip tie holder to frame
-Tape washers to battery 60mm apart at the center

title: Stackable Filament Holder with fully printable parts

description.text:
Here's my #FilamentChallenge. I wanted this to be print-and-play so even the bearings in the tube are 3D printed in place. Use the mid-beams to stack holders laterally and the puzzle-piece base allows fore and aft stacking (the multiple guide holes allow for guided back row spools). I'll add clips to pinch spool filaments that aren't being used.

This is one of my first designs with AutoDesk Inventor so I'd love advice or constructive criticism. Even with the base separated in half, the bottom piece is still just out of my printer's range, but I have printed the remaining pieces and they work fine. I'll add an adapter for the 53mm spools. I made this mostly for the challenge since I'm out of filament, but I think it could work well for many different printers.

Let me know if I should change anything or add specific adapters, thanks.

The only challenging print is the tube, which is composed of 3 pieces that must be printed together. I printed this piece with ABS at 60% with external supports and no shells. Use the version with shifted bearings - they sit on the bottom of their well instead of the center. Once printed, remove all supporting structure and gently twist the two tubes against each other to break the bearings loose. You can also squirt some acetone into the bearings to help shape them. I'll try to help if anyone wants to make one, good luck!

comments.text:
Hi Jodino, you seem to be able to print quite fine things with your Fabrikator. I have also one and i am still struggling with tuning. Can you share some advice about what brand PLA filament are you using, what is the slicer software you use (Cura ? Slic3r ?), which config parameters you have for this soft ? I tried cura but not satisfied with the result, and Slic3r is far better but much more parameters are available and cannot stabilize the tuning.
Thanks for any advice you could share.
comments.author: milcent

comments.text:
Hi!
thank you so much..I appreciate so much your interest.
Fabrikator 3D is a quite good printer..being my first printer, I spent a lot of hours tuning and learning on my own how to set it up in the best way.
-First I have calibrated the X Y and Z axis printing squares and cubes taken from thingiverse and modifying the steps in the firmware menu on the printer to obtain the piece printed in the right dimension.
-Then I have reduced the flow via the slicer (both cura and slic3r) of the extruder because printing the gears each teeth was "fat" and gear doesn't turn smoothly.(Finally I reduced the flow via printer's screen in the CONTROL--MOTION menu reducing E-step from 80.00 to 78.50..but for someone this is not the right way to modify the flow...because in this way you modify the mm that extruder extrudes..)
-Last step is to reduce (not to much) print speed..now I print between 60 and 70mm/sec.(slower the nozzle can drain some melted PLA and leave some blob on the piece)
-Increase the retraction speed to avoid leaking melted PLA from the nozzle
-Decrease nozzle temperature (now I am at 180C)
-I use esun (Hobbyking) and dutch PLA
comments.author: milcent

comments.text:
Thanks Jodino, i appreciate you take time to answer me and give such details.
Could you share the screenshots with me at this email : pierre (DOT) milcent (AT) gmail (DOT) com.
I also would like to see a copy of the firmware changes you made for modifying the steps. Did you apply the changes in the arduino firmware ?
For axes calmibration i followed the video of HobbyKing which mainly calibrates the Z axes.
I print with PLA at 200-210 (sure too hot), i use the bed to have the object sticks to the support, but when cooling it is bending ...
And i think with speed for printing is between 45 and 85mm/s as defined in SLic3r for perimeter or infill.
comments.author: jodino

comments.text:
Mail sent.. looking forward for your reply.
cheers
comments.author: milcent

comments.text:

thanks for your help provided. I am now printing quite well, still improving each time a little more, but very happy with current achievement and objects printed.
Regards, Pierre

title: Plate holder for SmartrapCore with Andreas alternate Z

description.text:
If you've ever needed to fix anything in the underbelly of your SmartrapCore (like checking wires, or trying to find that damn tiny M3 nut that accidentally felt somewhere in there), you know how annoying it is to have the printing plate falling on your hands.

I've already designed a plate holder to resolve this (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:815843), but it was before I started using Andreas's new Z system (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:896556), which is really great, but can't benefit from that so useful little hook.

So… I designed a new one, that can be used with the new Z, yeah! :)

Update : here's a new one designed to fit 8mm axis rods ! :)

Beware : this new accessory is extremely difficult to use… Instead of hooking it up on a X axis bar, you'll have to use one of the Y axis bars. Yeah, I know, nobody could have ever guessed that. That's why I put it in the instructions part. ;)

description.text:
First : I can not offer any warranty about this thing. If you use it it's to you check if it fit your need.

Having a passive cooling Xeon Phi but need an active one ? This can be a solution.

Update on 04/14/2016:

Having my Xeon-Phi working (appear in lspci), it heat hard! It need a more important airflow and so change my fans (buy 2 of this ones) and my design (blue on pictures, the old one is orange) to make openings bigger, airflow more linear (avoiding the 45° bend), thinner walls and attach point to help carrying the hardware.

Note that's noisy.

Printer:

OverLord Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print it fans side down, Xeon-Phi side up.

The fixation to the coprocessor is done by four M3x10 bolts, fixations of fans are done by eight 3mm or 3.5mm wood screw (see the picture).

Nut's space in the shape is a bit small, this help holding the bolts when fixing the adaptor on the coprocessor. The insertion can be done with pliers or by screwing (see the pictures).

comments.text: Well some physics - the entry port on the phi is approx equiv to a 64mm fan ( sqrt(90*34/pi)). I calculated the exponential dropoff (an extra support in the loft) so that the narrowing was approximately the same area.  I had considered fully specifying the shape of the loft, so keep the transitition close to constant (3000mm^2), but I'm kind of in a hurry to see a result - of course ;-)

comments.text: Excellent work! Fits like a glove and the fans mount spot on! It doesn't add too much length to an already large piece of hardware. This fit in my CORSAIR Carbide case with room to spare. I used two Delta 40mm fans that displace 24 CFM each. My card idles at around 45C, and only gets up 55C with all cores running. With a fan controller, I can run the fans at about half speed to keep it quiet and the core temperature only gets up to about 65C with all cores running. Your design solves a huge challenge with these passive cards.

This is a spool holder that uses a 55 mm printed bearing to roll the spool, and also has a filament guider which slides along the x direction, stopping the filament from slacking outside the spool and tangling itself thus ruining your print. easy disassembly and assembly

assembly guide,

step 1: fit spool inside base.
step 2: slide roller shaft through roller hole on base and through spool.
step 3: fit 3D printed bearing into both roller shaft and base hole.
step 4: fit filament guide on guide rail.
step 5: fit guide rail on base.
step 6: enjoy tangle free prints.

Made in TinkerCAD

I needed to cut am 20cm wide and 18mm high board and the side had to be in a 90° angle with a nice straight cut.
So i designed this guide for my japanese Kataba saw.
To get the guide completed you will need 4 threaded rods with nuts. I used M5 *330mm rods and it worked great.
Until now I have used this guide for 8 boards and it seems to work great with my Kataba.

The slot is only 1mm wide so it is perfect for japanese saws. If you want to use other saws you will probably have to widen the slot.

printed with 2 layers of 0,2mm ABS filament and 15% infill. I am sure other combinations will work good.
Make sure the guide is laying flat for printing so the grain can handle the force from the rods better.

author: Maztah

description.text: This is my design for the Filament Challenge. I used the dimensions that Makerbot gives on their site for the Spool seeing as I don't have access to one. The Base is easily printable, using very little supports and can be used with a peg board or with screws directly. The Lid flips down to protect the filament from dust and UV rays, additionally it features a hole at the top to allow the filament to be fed to the printer without ever leaving the holder. Finally the Arms are attached after the spool is put in place to hold the spool to the Base. Use the Pin to easily tell whether the spool is ABS or PLA.

Print the Base with a lower infill on its larger base, so the Makerbot logo is upright, and use supports for the protruding pins. The Lid has a flat top, which should be the base during the print. Definitely use supports for that. Pins and arms should be a simple, supportless print.

Because this isn't a part that takes a load 25-30% infill is sufficient

Then mount your sensor and bracket to the channel, enjoy!

I recently purchased a Timbuk2 Red Hook Crit backpack, and it is fantastic except for the length of the shoulder and sternum straps. When biking, they flap around and are an annoyance, so I designed these incredibly simple clips to keep the straps together.

The clips were designed to fit the 15 mm sternum strap and the 20 mm shoulder straps on the Timbuk2 Red Hook Crit backpack, however it was designed in OpenSCAD so it should be easily customizable​ to fit your needs.
The clip was designed in OpenSCAD and printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with 100% infill.
